docs.lead_paragraph: Anthem Inc. said yesterday that it would go to court to overturn the California insurance commissioner's rejection of its $16.4 billion merger with WellPoint Health Systems Inc. The merger with WellPoint, which is based in Thousand Oaks, Calif., would combine the nation's two largest Blue Cross Blue Shield companies and create the nation's largest health insurance company. California's Department of Insurance withheld approval of the merger Friday, saying it would pull millions of dollars out of California, hurt health care quality for consumers and give too much severance pay to executives. ''Our response will be to bring legal action in a California state court,'' Larry C. Glasscock, the chief executive of Anthem, told analysts in a conference call. Anthem also reported earnings and said it earned $237.9 million, or $1.66 a share, during the quarter ended June 30, compared with $177.3 million, or $1.25 a share, a year earlier.

headline.main: ANTHEM TO CHALLENGE CALIFORNIA'S REJECTION OF MERGER

docs.abstract: Anthem Inc will sue to overturn California insurance commissioner's rejection of its $16.4 billion merger with WellPoint Health Systems (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Bush administration announced plans on Tuesday to pay for initial comprehensive physical examinations for new Medicare beneficiaries, starting next year, and it said Medicare would also cover screening tests for cholesterol and diabetes for people already in the program. As a result of incremental changes in the last few years, Medicare now covers a wide variety of preventive services.

docs.lead_paragraph: The F.B.I. has rescinded health benefits that it says were mistakenly given to the same-sex partner of an agent. Katy Gossman, an agent in New Haven, received an e-mail message from the bureau informing her that her partner, Kristin, would be removed from her health plan. A spokesman for the bureau, Bill Carter, said the approval had been a mistake and an oversight. The government does not allow benefits for same-sex spouses, Mr. Carter said. The couple had been receiving spousal benefits since May 30, Ms. Gossman said. They were married in May in Massachusetts.

headline.main: National Briefing | New England: Massachusetts: Benefits For Lesbian Spouse

docs.lead_paragraph: They came to see the Howard Dean they loved and lost, and there he was. Hurling a donkey at a life-size picture of Vice President Dick Cheney. Letting out a toned-down version of the infamous ''Yee-aahh!'' scream that hastened his demise after the Iowa caucuses. Giving the green light to attacking President Bush. He urged his backers to do more than vote. ''Voting will get you a D,'' Dr. Dean told 200 members of a union that had endorsed his bid for the White House.

byline.original: By JODI WILGOREN and RANDAL C. ARCHIBOLD

docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials plan to announce a proposal today that could save taxpayers at least $16 billion over the next decade by slashing the amounts Medicare pays for more than two dozen cancer and lung drugs, a move almost certain to raise an outcry among cancer specialists and some drug companies. The health care industry has been bracing for rollbacks. But until today's report, few outside the Medicare agency have known the extent of the price cuts, which for some drugs would be as much as 89 percent below current levels. Besides saving the government money, the changes would directly benefit Medicare recipients, who pay 20 percent of the prices their doctors charge for the drugs.

headline.main: Proposal Would Cut What Medicare Pays for Cancer Drugs

docs.abstract: Federal health officials to announce proposal that could save taxpayers at least $16 billion over next decade by slashing amounts Medicare pays for more than two dozen cancer and lung drugs, move almost certain to raise outcry from cancer specialists and some drug companies; changes would save government money and directly benefit Medicare recipients, who pay 20 percent of prices their doctors charge for drugs; Federal officials estimate changes would reduce typical cancer doctor's Medicare revenue by 8 percent next year; changes result from last year's Medicare drug law (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: HCA, the nation's largest hospital chain, said yesterday that second-quarter profit jumped 47 percent because of a reduction in malpractice insurance expenses. But bad debt continued to plague the company as more patients left bills unpaid. Net income climbed to $352 million, or 72 cents a share, from $240 million, or 47 cents, a year earlier, HCA said in a statement. Revenue rose 6.7 percent, to $5.83 billion. The company is based in Nashville.

headline.main: Hospital Chain Says Profit Soared 47% in Quarter

docs.lead_paragraph: Franklin Roosevelt spoke of the ''forgotten man,'' Bill Clinton of the ''forgotten middle class.'' Now the Democratic Party of Senator John Kerry is reaching for that long -- and politically successful -- legacy with a promise to ease the ''middle-class squeeze'' and restore the booming economy of the Clinton years. To that end, the Democratic National Convention on Monday night offered a simple message about the economy: It was better under the Democrats. The middle class had a brighter future. And Mr. Kerry has a plan to restore middle-class prosperity -- to stem the loss of jobs overseas, to ease the burden of rising health, education and energy costs on families, to get the nation's fiscal house and economy in order.

headline.main: A Simple Message Aimed at the Middle

docs.abstract: News analysis: simple message being promoted during Democratic National Convention is that economy was better under Democrats, and that John Kerry has plan to restore middle-class prosperity; former Pres Bill Clinton, in his address, scoffs at Republicans' decision to give big tax cuts to wealthy Americans like himself while, he claims, shortchanging critical national needs like education; criticizes Republicans for turning huge surplus into deficit; urges voters to choose Kerry-Edwards ticket, claiming 'our way works better'; although Kerry has stressed national security issues, economy remains central issue in swing states that will decide general election this fall, so speaker after speaker at convention addresses need for more--and better paying--jobs, shift in national priorities and return to Democratic economic policies (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Following are excerpts from a speech by Hillary Rodham Clinton last night at the Democratic National Convention in Boston, as recorded by The New York Times. A full transcript is at nytimes.com/campaigns. I am practically speechless. However, 12 years ago, when our country needed new leadership, Americans selected a Democrat who gave us eight years of peace, prosperity and promise. Tonight, I have the pleasure of introducing the last great Democratic president. But first I want to say a few words about the next great Democratic president, John Kerry.

headline.main: Hillary Clinton: 'A Safer and More Secure Future'
